) The TIGTA/GAO liaison is the primary point of contact for audits. The Responsibilities GAO liaison will notify each SB/SE OU functional coordinator of an meeting. Each OU functional coordinator will advise the TIGTA/GAO liaison the name of the OU POC for that audit. The OU POCs and executives pate in meetings and serve as the secondary POCs for the auditors. The TIGTA/GAO liaison coordinates with the SB/SE functional coordinators to: a. Ensure all impacted stakeholders are engaged in the audit. b. Review the scope and objectives of the audit. c. Provide all impacted operating divisions with an opportunity to respond. d. Prepare timely responses. e. Monitor corrective actions. f. Provide periodic status updates. g. Facilitate delivery of requested case files in a timely manner. h. Facilitate requests for interviews of field or campus personnel. i. Direct activities as needed. j. Review assigned audit information entered into the SB/SE audit and update the audit record weekly as the audit progresses. (

) After the TIGTA/GAO liaison has provided GAO/TIGTA with the executive secondary POC information, the auditor can request information from the liaison, the functional coordinator, the executive, the secondary POC, or

GAO/TIGTA will include the TIGTA/GAO liaison in all information requests submitted in writing, sent via e
mail, or received by telephone. The functional coordinator, executive, secondary POC or other personnel forward an e

mail to notify the TIGTA/GAO liaison of all verbal information requests received from GAO/TIGTA. The TIGTA/GAO liaison is responsible monitoring, tracking, and accurately documenting all audit activity and must maintain ongoing communication with the functional coordinator, executive secondary POCs and GAO/TIGTA auditors. As appropriate, auditors will contact the TIGTA/GAO liaison for additional assistance in obtaining information. The functional coordinator, secondary POCs and other personnel must the following guidelines when sharing information and data or meeting with auditors: a. Ensure information requested in engagement letters is available for auditors at the opening conference. b. Ensure information and data requested during audits is provided to the auditors in a reasonable and timely manner. In general, a maximum of weeks is considered timely.

) GAO audits the financial statements of IRS annually with the objective of rendering an opinion, evaluating internal controls, and reporting IRS’s ance. (
) At the conclusion of the audit, GAO issues an opinion on the financial ments. The final report is issued annually by November

) The Opinion rendered as one of the following: a. Unmodified Opinion – In all material aspects, the statements fairly represent financial data and operations. b. Qualified Opinion – Except for the circumstances specified in the the statements fairly present financial data and operations. c. Adverse Opinion – The auditor disagrees with application of certain counting principles, and statements do not fairly represent financial d. Disclaimer Opinion – The auditor could not obtain enough evidential matter to express an opinion. An unfavorable audit opinion on IRS’ financial statements impairs ability to place reliance on the Treasury and Government-wide statements. (

December – GAO initiates the audit by issuing the entrance letter through Legislative Affairs, who sends it to the CFO, the lead stakeholder. The

Small CFO controls and forwards the letter to the BODs. Each of the BODs appoints a liaison who is responsible for coordinating the audit activities. In SB/SE, a TIGTA/GAO liaison coordinates activities and ensures complete coverage and timely responses. b. February – March – GAO begins to requests documents via Prepared/ Provided by Client (PBC) Listing. BODs are responsible for items in their organization. GAO may also request a walk-through to understand how work is processed. The CFO circulates Cycle Memoranda, that describe IRS’s operations/processes. There are three memoranda which SB/SE reviews and updates: (cid:
) Revenue Receipts (cid:
) Refunds (cid:

) Unpaid Assessments The Financial Audit liaison coordinates review/update of the memoranda. c. February – September – CFO hosts monthly conference calls to discuss PBC Listing updates and other items submitted by GAO or IRS. d. March – April – Internal Control Testing at Field Offices. GAO conducts field testing over various aspects of field offices whose responsibilities include receiving taxpayer payments and returns and forwarding them for further processing. GAO issues a letter to the CFO identifying the sites where they plan to conduct field testing one to two weeks prior to the In recent years, GAO has performed this testing in Collection field The TIGTA/GAO liaison works with the OU coordinator to plan visitations and provide CFO and GAO with points of contact for each office. GAO hosts entrance and exit conferences at the end of each site visit in which the TIGTA/GAO liaison documents the summary findings. e. May – June – GAO issues Matters for Further Consideration (MFCs) which are the findings from the internal control testing at the field offices. IRS agrees with or refutes the facts identified in the MFC. IRS submits proposed resolutions addressing issues with which they concur. If IRS does not concur with the issue, it is required to support the position on refuted situation/circumstances. During this time, GAO also issues Audit Inquiry Forms (AIFs) which relate to specific issues GAO needs clarifica- tion or additional information. f. June – September – GAO conducts transaction testing on sample cases for the Unpaid Assessment, Revenue Receipts, and Refund audits at the Kansas City campus. g. October – November – CFO issues the After the Audit Report from the transaction testing. The majority of SB/SE findings are from the Unpaid Assessment sample. Responses to the reports are due by December
h. November

– GAO issues a draft opinion on the financial statements qualified, qualified, adverse, etc.), including other high-level data, weaknesses, and reportable conditions. IRS has four hours to coordinate the review by the executives. i. November

– GAO issues final opinion on the financial statements and reports the opinion to Treasury. j. December – CFO requests the current statuses of open in the current GAO report, Status of GAO Financial Audit and Related Management Report Recommendations which are due by December
k. Quarterly – CFO requests updates to open recommendations (March, June, and September).

) SB/SE’s goal is to establish achievable corrective action due dates. For tency throughout SB/SE, use the

th of the month as the due date for all corrective actions. Delaying actions should be rare; however, certain delays, such as those relating to funding, IRM clearance and publication, executive steering committee concurrences, and Work Request (WR) prioritization, be necessary. (

) To ensure achievable due dates, the TIGTA/GAO liaison will advise the OUs to: a. Brainstorm when findings and recommendations are first presented. b. Discuss and evaluate each recommendation. c. Consider all obstacles when establishing due dates. d. Draft a timeline including major milestone dates to arrive at the date. e. Add additional time to allow for unforeseen obstacles. f. Carefully consider the scheduling of due dates when the report includes numerous recommendations where one corrective action must be completed before work can begin on another action. (
) The final report phase (Congressional

The JAMES Coordinator is responsible for coordinating implementation of management corrective actions in response to TIGTA and GAO audit recom- mendations. The coordinator should: a. Forward JAMES verification memoranda and any other OIC memoranda to the appropriate offices (Directors, Senior Operations Advisors, and Functional Coordinators) within SB/SE to request verification of the infor- mation provided. b. Request status updates from Directors on the open TIGTA and GAO cor- rective actions. c. Review for accuracy and consolidate Corrective Action Status Update forms received from SB/SE Directors. d. Brief SB/SE Directors, or their functional coordinators, on problems or issues dealing with updates to TIGTA and GAO corrective actions. e. Prepare regular reports on the status of open TIGTA and GAO corrective actions and provide copies to pertinent SB/SE Directors and Managers. f. Assist analysts or functional coordinators with the preparation of concur- rence memoranda for changes or closure of planned TIGTA or GAO corrective actions not implemented as planned and forward them to the OIC. g. Assist analysts or functional liaisons with the preparation of transfer memoranda to other IRS operating divisions and forward them to the ap- propriate offices. h. Answer questions from the OIC on status updates. i. Forward monthly JAMES reports to pertinent offices in SB/SE. j. Maintain records on JAMES audit verification memoranda, management updates to corrective actions, and related documents for each of the reports and corrective actions (e.g., maintain a corrective actions database). k. Act as liaison between SB/SE managers and the OIC on resolution of problems encountered during implementation of actions and during cation of status updates. l. Provide guidance to functional coordinators and managers on audit follow-up policy and procedures and brief heads of functional areas the status of the open inventory, as needed. ) Legislative Affairs (LA) monitors proposed/pending legislation (bills) as part their oversight and coordination role. LA analyzes and tracks developing lation that may affect IRS programs until Congress suspends activity on the or passes it. a. Proposed bills are those being formulated or considered for passage by Congressional Subcommittees, Congressional Committees, Conference Committees, U.S. House of Representatives or U.S. Senate. Pending are those that have passed both houses but have not been signed into law by the President. b. LA tracks bills of greatest interest to Treasury and IRS as they progress through the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Committee to enactment by the full Congress. (

) In addition, LA issues weekly updates via e-mail on pending legislation. Any IRS employee can review the status of pending legislation by accessing the IRWeb page, selecting “Research” then selecting “THOMAS” and entering a key word search. LA and TIGTA/GAO also have subscriptions to additional research sites, such as Congressional Quarterly (CQ), that provide and timely information. (

) LA serves as the principal liaison between IRS leadership and the IRS Operating Divisions for implementing legislation. a. The liaison then forwards to the designated OU coordinators. b. ) The TIGTA/GAO liaison has responsibility for coordinating implementation of each SB/SE-owned legislative provision. a. Each SB/SE OU provides the TIGTA/GAO liaison with an OU coordinator. Once an OU coordinator receives the legislative information, it is dissemi- nated throughout their organization for review and analysis. ) Legislative Proposals are suggestions for legislation that will further the tives of the IRS Strategic Plan (such as reducing the tax gap) to improve service and compliance. Legislative proposals may seek to address an area noncompliance, reduce the burden or complexity of tax administration, or technical corrections to rectify oversights or omissions. (

) Legislative Proposals are submitted in two ways: a. From internal sources, including SB/SE staff and offices, the SB/SE missioner, other IRS BODs or organizations, and the IRS Commissioner. b. From external sources, including practitioners, stakeholder organizations, Treasury, other Federal Agencies and Congress. (

) The Deputy Commissioner presents to the IRS Commissioner legislative proposals cleared by the IRS BODs. Proposals approved by the are sent to Treasury for review and consideration. Treasury will consult with OMB and the Taxpayer Advocate on the proposals. Proposals approved by Treasury and OMB are shared with Congress for possible inclusion in future legislation. (
) Legislative Affairs monitors the progress of legislative proposals once they approved within IRS and ready for submission to Treasury for clearance and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Requests for published guidance seek clarification and/or changes to legislation as well as to existing published guidance (i.e. policies, etc.). Requests for guidance strive to promote consistent treatment and tax administration, resolve a frequently litigated issue, lessen burden on taxpayers and the Service, and/or enable taxpayers to more easily or comply with tax law.
